Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 1554 ("Roadmap and implementation plan for cyber adoption of artificial intelligence")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 1554 ("Roadmap and implementation plan for cyber adoption of artificial intelligence")
Short summary: Requires the Commander of the United States Cyber Command and the Chief Information Officer of the Department of Defense to develop a five-year implementation plan for rapidly adopting and acquiring artificial intelligence systems to support the Department of Defense.
Long summary:
Requires the Commander of the United States Cyber Command and the Chief Information Officer of the Department of Defense to develop a five-year implementation plan for rapidly adopting artificial intelligence systems to support the Department of Defense. 

The plan shall: 

(a) Identify and prioritize AI systems and data that currently affect, or may benefit in the future, the Department's cybersecurity and cyber operations. 

(b) Lay out a plan to acquire AI systems and data identified in part (a).

(c) Identify relevant skill deficiencies.

(d) Identify opportunities to solicit AI system operator feedback.

(e) Identify and address long term technology gaps for the Department's cyber war fighting mission.

(f) Evaluate the risks posed by adversary AI-based attacks.

(g) Furnish a timeline with target milestones, investments, and required expenditures.
 
(h) Incorporate metrics to evaluate AI adoption.

(i) Identify further funding, authorities, and policies that may be necessary.

(j) Define a maturity model describing desired cyber capabilities independent of specific technology solutions.

Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to assess threats posed by unmanned aerial system swarms to installations and deployed Armed Forces, the use of these swarms by adversaries and their national security implications such as autonomous intelligence and machine learning, current capabilities of the Defense Department and their effectiveness in countering these threats, and efforts by the Defense Department to develop and field technology that can counter swarms.

Casual name: Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act, Title III ("National Science Foundation for the Future")
Short summary: Provides scholarships and fellowships for AI-related studies to recruit and train the next generation of AI professionals in US government. Grants competitive grants and fellowships for organizations advancing risk assessment through AI. Adds AI and machine learning to the list of research areas that the Director of the National Science Foundation can award grants to. Makes awards available for supporting basic research to advance critical minerals mining strategies that involve AI. Requires the development and testing of models to inform implementation of government-wide data infrastructure for statistical activities. Requires a study on U.S. higher education's AI research capacity and an annual update to key technology focus areas.
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of the National Science Foundation (Director) to develop a report on the need and feasibility as well as construct plans to implement a program to recruit and train the next generation of AI professionals in US government. Mandates that the report include statistical data on the federal AI workforce, assessments of current and future demand for AI expertise across the federal government and the ability of higher education institutions to prepare students to meet this demand, and an evaluation of the need for and feasibility of establishing a scholarship-for-service program for AI professionals in US government, as well as the possibility of leveraging existing programs such as the Federal Cyber Scholarship-for-Service Program. 

Authorizes the Director and other appropriate agency heads to establish a Federal AI scholarship-for-service program to recruit and train AI professionals to achieve the missions of US government. Requires the Director, in coordination with other agency heads, to establish criteria such as excellence in AI education and the ability to attract diverse students to designate qualified institutions of higher education that shall be eligible to participate in the program. Requires the program to provide scholarships through qualified higher education institutions to students pursuing fields of study related to AI, provide scholarship recipients with temporary appointments related to work on AI in the federal government, prioritize placement of scholarship recipients in executive agencies, identify opportunities to promote multidisciplinary programs of study, support capacity building for educational institutions to enable them to train the next-generation AI workforce, create courses in technology ethics for scholarship recipients, and award fellowships to masters and doctoral students who are pursuing degrees or research in AI and related fields. Instructs scholarship amounts to cover a student’s tuition and fees for not more than 3 years with an additional stipend, and obligates scholarship recipients to work for a period of time equivalent to the length of the scholarship in the AI mission of the US government entity or affiliated entity.

Instructs the Director to establish competitive awards to institutions to advance knowledge of risk assessment including the utilization of AI in our ability to understand and predict extreme events and natural hazards, create engineered system solutions and develop instrumentation for innovation in resilient infrastructure, and advance research on multidisciplinary wildfire science and behaviors related to increasing resilience.

Amends Section 506(a) of the America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 by adding AI and machine learning to the list of research areas that fall under information technologies for manufacturing that the Director can award grants to.

Instructs the Director to make competitive awards to institutions to support basic research to advance critical minerals mining strategies to make better use of domestic resources and eliminate national reliance on minerals subject to supply chain disruptions, including the application of AI for geological exploration of critical minerals and the application of machine learning for detection and sorting of critical minerals.

Requires the Director to conduct or support the development of a study on AI research capacity at US institutions of higher education. Requires the study to, at minimum, address which universities are putting out significant peer-reviewed AI research based on quantity and number of citations, which factors of these universities such as computing power enable their research, promising practices at these universities for advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion in AI research programs, geographic diversity of universities that have AI research-enabling factors, and how universities that are not currently top producers of AI research could improve, including potential pilot programs that the federal government could develop or support to help universities produce AI research.

Instructs the Director, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget and the interagency committee established under the National AI Initiative Act of 2020, to develop and test models to inform the implementation of a government-wide data linkage and access infrastructure for statistical activities.

Requires the Director to identify, and annually review and update a list of not more than 10 key technology focus areas, which includes AI, machine learning, autonomy, and related advances.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title XCII, Section 9203 ("Spectrum information technology modernization efforts")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XCII, Section 9203 ("Spectrum information technology modernization efforts")
Short summary: A directive for covered agencies, including the Department of Defense, to employ updated algorithms, data, and AI tools in modernizing their infrastructure for managing Federal spectrum. This involves enhancing efficiency, validation, accuracy, modeling, and monitoring, with a specific emphasis on automated adjustments, collaborative spectrum sharing, and interoperability, while also mandating comprehensive plans, reviews, and oversight to ensure effective implementation and integration of these AI-driven advancements.
Long summary:
Use updated algorithms, data, AI tools, and algorithms to modernize infrastructure. Ways to improve infrastructure include efficiency, validation, accuracy, modeling, and monitoring. The directive aims to enhance covered agencies' capacity to meet mission requirements in congested Federal spectrum environments through the implementation of automated adjustments, the creation of a time-based mechanism for collaborative spectrum sharing among agencies, and fostering collaboration to ensure interoperability. 

Within 240 days of the enactment of this Act, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information is required to submit to Congress a report outlining a plan for the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) to modernize and automate its infrastructure for managing the use of Federal spectrum by covered agencies, with the goal of improving efficiency in spectrum management in ways such as a timeline for implementation, plans for security enhancement, data model improvement, and workflow automation. 

Within one year of the enactment of this Act, the head of each covered agency is required to submit a report to the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information and the Policy and Plans Steering Group outlining a plan to modernize the agency's infrastructure. Each submitted report must include an assessment of their current capabilities, a timeline for completion, management capabilities, agency requirements or restrictions, existing infrastructure, and a plan for safe integration of government data.

The Comptroller General of the United States is mandated to conduct a review of covered agencies' infrastructure within 180 days of the Act's enactment and subsequently oversee the implementation of modernization plans submitted by the Assistant Secretary and covered agencies, providing regular reports and briefings to relevant congressional committees until December 31, 2030. The term "covered agency" includes any Federal entity, as determined by the Assistant Secretary, encompassing the Department of Defense, and "infrastructure" is defined as information technology systems and related tools and databases.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, Section 216 ("Improvements relating to steering committee on emerging technology and national security threats")
Casual name: FY2022 NDAA, Section 216 ("Improvements relating to steering committee on emerging technology and national security threats")
Short summary: Amends Section 236 of the FY 2021 National Defense Authorization Act by changing the structure of a steering committee on emerging technology and national security and featuring the intelligence community more prominently in the steering committee's responsibilities.
Long summary:
Amends Section 236 of the FY 2021 National Defense Authorization Act by adding the Director of National Intelligence as an official that can, with the Secretary of Defense, establish a steering committee on emerging technology and national security and receive recommendations from the committee. Amends members of the steering committee to consist of the Principal Deputy Director of National Intelligence, the Deputy Sector of Defense, the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staffs, and other appropriate officials. Adds that the Steering Committee shall be chaired by the Deputy Secretary of Defense, the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the Principal Deputy Director of National Intelligence jointly.

Amends the responsibilities of the steering committee by clarifying that the committee's strategy is to maintain the technological superiority of both the US military and intelligence community according to not only the National Defense Strategy, but also the National Intelligence Strategy and the National Security Strategy. Adds that the steering committee is responsible for making recommendations on any changes to the guidance for developing the National Intelligence Program budget and determining whether sufficient resources are available for the intelligence community, in addition to the Department of Defense, to defeat threats to the US.

Adds that the list of technologies classified as emerging technologies is to be determined jointly by the Secretary of Defense and the Director of National Intelligence. Adds the definition of intelligence community from the National Security Act of 1947.

Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Defense to study the use of unmanned ground vehicle systems by the Department of Defense manufactured by certain foreign entities.

Requires submission of a report to congressional defense committees within 180 days, assessing usage, national security threats, and identifying foreign manufacturers.

Calls for the evaluation of cybersecurity risks, technological vulnerabilities, and the foreign entities' military-civil nexus.

Demands an assessment of the feasibility of the Defense Innovation Unit developing a list of U.S. manufacturers.

Mandates an evaluation of whether a prohibition on procuring and operating these systems is advisable for U.S. national security.

Prohibits procurement and operation of these systems by the Department of Defense one year after the report submission, unless deemed in the national interest.

Exempts this prohibition if recommended as not in the best national security interest.
